descriptionSet.description: A postcard is stamped in red with Eid greetings and an Urdu couplet referring to the cheering up of Muslims’ hearts and the fulfilling of their prayers. The postcard shows also a sailing ship, a bunch of flowers and a fountain. The card may have originally been produced for distribution on board ships, although its reverse side is completely blank. Unused, circa 1930, publisher unknown.

inscription.text: عید مبارک ، عید آی ہے ہوے مومنوں کے قلب شاد
Eid Mubarak, Eid ayi hai, hue sab mominon ke qalb shad, Fazl-e-haq se aaj bar aai har ik dil ki murad; Aap ko bhi ho mubarak ye khushi ye jashn-e-Eid; Ien dua-e-raqim-e-khasta jigar maqbul baad.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

titleSet.title: Eid greeting card depicting a sailing steamer

hra:item.hra:value: text-ur: عید مبارک ، عید آی ہے ہوے مومنوں کے قلب شاد

text-transcription-ur: Eid Mubarak, Eid ayi hai, hue sab mominon ke qalb shad, Fazl-e-haq se aaj bar aai har ik dil ki murad; Aap ko bhi ho mubarak ye khushi ye jashn-e-Eid; Ien dua-e-raqim-e-khasta jigar maqbul baad.

description-en: A postcard is stamped in red with Eid greetings and an Urdu couplet referring to the cheering up of Muslims’ hearts and the fulfilling of their prayers. The postcard shows also a sailing ship, a bunch of flowers and a fountain. The card may have originally been produced for distribution on board ships, although its reverse side is completely blank. Unused, circa 1930, publisher unknown. (ys)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This greeting card might be referring to the cheering up of Muslims’ hearts and the fulfilling of their prayers. With an image of a sailing ship, the card may have originally been produced for distribution on board ships, although its reverse side is completely blank. (Yousuf Saeed)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The choice of the image may not be unintentional: a sailing ship can symbolise many things for Eid including sending of greetings across long distances, a desire of travel to meet someone on Eid, a pilgrimage, and of course a sign of European “novelty” since the arrival of a ship meant the coming of new imported goods or people. But the sailing ship and handshake could be just a few of several transnational icons that were being adopted for such cards. (Yousuf Saeed)(gs)

related literature: Mathur, Saloni, "Wanted Native Views: Collecting colonial postcards of India," in Antionette Burton (ed.) Gender, Sexuality and Colonial Modernities, New York: Routledge, 1999, 95-115. (gs)
related literature: Patterson, Steven, Postcards from the Raj, Patterns of Prejudice, Volume 40, Number 2, Routledge, May 2006, 142-158; also see Saloni Mathur, 1999. (gs)

related hyperlinks: http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/117/index_1.html, last accessed 2011-04-07, Saeed, Yousuf 2011. "Eid Mubarak: Cross-cultural Image Exchange in Muslim South Asia.". (gs)
Patterson, Steven, Postcards from the Raj, Patterns of Prejudice, Volume 40, Number 2, Routledge, May 2006, 142-158; also see Saloni Mathur, 1999.
Mathur, Saloni, "Wanted Native Views: Collecting colonial postcards of India," in Antionette Burton (ed.) Gender, Sexuality and Colonial Modernities, New York: Routledge, 1999, 95-115.
Saeed, Yousuf 2011. "Eid Mubarak: Cross-cultural Image Exchange in Muslim South Asia.".
